content:
I don't understand why the last validator has A and B of different lengths. All the test cases and validators except it have an even length of A and B.

0 < Length of A and B < 10 implies that A and B have the same length.

There is no indication that they might be of different lengths. The only point of validators is to test if the solution is hardcoded and it shouldn't fail if it isn't.

Hi MSWS ! there is a mistake in your stub :-( !
-> The B "SmallWord" is very much longeur than 1 ...
=> You may use "string" and size it to at least 9+1 ;-) !
Made some changes to the format of the problem statement.

I would expect "round normally" to mean round to the closest integer. Your requested outputs always round up.
e.g. test "YOOOOOOO" rounds 14.2 to 15.

The statement is missing information on the expected rounding - e.g. half half way: should 10 * .25 be 2 or 3?

The expected result of test 'REEEEEE' looks wrong, it has 24 Rs for a 0.23 progress.

Hey! A few concerns, if you will:
- The problem statement needs to specify how we should be rounding the progress. To illustrate it simply, let's say the bar was 10 items long and the progress was 0.45. Should this be "XXXX------" or "XXXXX-----"? Should we be rounding down, up, or in between?
- I'm wondering why you constrained progress from being equal to 0 or 1?
- "How many characters L the bar should use Not always its length" Would find a better way to describe this "character". A string with L characters has a length of L, always. The confusion is where you describe "[]" as one *character* as an example, but it's confusing to describe it as a "character" even though it includes 2 characters. How do we know which one you mean when you say "character"?

Thank you for your feedback!

I have added a statement in regards to the rounding, hopefully that will help clear things up.

The progress is not constrained at being either 1 or 0, it is constrained at being greater than 0 and less than 1.

I will figure out a better way of saying how the characters/lengths work, thanks for pointing out the confusion.
Thank you for your feedback. I've edited and made a small addition in regards to rounding. The REEEE question has been fixed, there was a mistake with using floats with doubles >.<
I will edit that, thanks for telling me.
I also had a similar issue when solving. I would reword "rounded upward". This wasn't clear at least to me.
I've added an example of when you why you would have to round and how you should to help others in the future. Thanks for the feedback.
Actually there are also more incorrect tests. See the number of Ys in "YOOOOOOO".
I will investigate further, thanks for pointing these out!
Fixed, I have clarified now that you’re supposed to round up.

Hm, I can't actually find the spot in the problem statement where you say you have specified the rounding method. Would you mind pointing it out to me? Sorry about that.

With the constraints, I meant to say that it would be okay IMO for progress to be equal to 0 or equal to 1 for this problem. As in:

0 ≤ PROG ≤ 1

Sorry, should have been clearer about that.

(Wow you reply quickly)

Anyways, the revision was made here: Line 4 A float PROG representing the progress of the bar, round normally if necessary.

If there is a better way I could word this please let me know. I suppose PROG could be equal to 0 or 1, I'll add that right now. Once again thank you for the suggestions and quick response.

Ah, OK, that wasn't there when I came to reply. Guess I should have been more patient haha

I'll approve this when I get the chance. Thanks for being willing to make the changes.
